clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Sonication on Periprosthetic Joint Infection Treatment Strategy.
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Sonication on Periprosthetic Joint Infection Treatment Strategy.

brief_summary.textblock: This research investigates the effect of periprosthetic joint infection on the final result of sonication.Treatment strategy will be planned in half of the patients according to the results of the conventional method and the other half in accordance with the method of sonication.

detailed_description.textblock: As in the whole world, total joint arthroplasty applications are increasing rapidly in our country. In addition, there is an increase in the number of periprosthetic joint infections. Sometimes the conventional microbiological examinations are not effective. For this reason, it seems more effective to verify the microbes "protected" from the body defense systems and antibiotic treatment by creating biofilms on prosthetic components compared to conventional methods. However, it is not clear in the literature how much the sonication method changed the method of periprosthetic joint infection treatment and the results. Therefore, the effect of sonication on these results may be important for orthopedic surgeons.

primary_outcome.measure: The success rate of revision arthropalsty
primary_outcome.description: The treatment strategy, which will be applied according to the sonication result, how much will affect success rate in revision arthroplasties.

arm_group.description: The treatment strategies of all patients in this group will be based on the culture results to be made by the sonication method.
The treatment strategies of all patients in this group will be based on the culture results to be made by the conventional method.

intervention.description: Sonication dislodges adherent bacteria from explanted prosthetics by ultrasound and may improve the diagnosis of periprosthetic joint infection.
Conventional methods are the evaluation of preoperative aspirated samples or intraoperative tissue cultures with standard microbiological methods.

study_pop.textblock: Patients who have undergone primary hip and knee arthroplasty and will require revision for any reason.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All patients scheduled for revision arthroplasty (aseptic revision, septic revision, instability, and periprosthetic fracture)
Exclusion Criteria:
- who do not accept randomization
- insufficient data for MSIS criteria
- acute periprosthetic infections
- patients with systemic inflammatory disease
- patients who received antibiotics for any reason at least 2 weeks before the operation
